TL;DR: You like the Scala type-system but find it complex sometimes? This workshop is made for you! Come discover Generalized Algebraic Data Types (GADT) through practicing many use-cases: type predicates, type refinement, expressing effects, implicit derivation, type-level programming, â€¦

Functional languages are appreciated due to the fact they are easy to use and their reliability to define and handle data structures close to the business: `case class`, `sealed trait`, *pattern-matching* (`match-case`), etcâ€¦ Some of them, like Scala, go even further by:

- Expressing predicates on types like â€œtype T is supported by the databaseâ€ or â€œtypes A et B are equalsâ€
- Restraining functions or `case class` to families of types like â€œthis function is defined only on types T supported by the databaseâ€
- Expressing algebraic effects like â€œthe database supports only these operationsâ€.
- Deriving implicits with regular functions which can inspect the structure of the type.
- Even type-level programming.
These structures are called Generalized Algebraic Data Types.

They are unfortunately reputed to be difficult to apprehend and not very useful. Our experience shows us you can come up with simple and effective solutions to the problems given above using GADT. This workshop, unlike usual presentations, will be focused on practical use cases. Its aim is to help the assistance develop their insight by practicing on these everyday situations and give them a practical toolkit to deal with these issues.

This workshop was designed to fit a large range of attendees, from the beginner, which already knows `case classes`, `sealed trait` et *pattern-matching* but has never heard about GADT, to the Scala type-level expert.
We are waiting for you.
